The best books for self improvement:

>1) The Genealogy of Morality - Friedrich Nietzsche

This book helps me come to a realization that the moral concept like equality or Justice is slave morality—which created by a slave to control the superior. This book makes me stop being naive. I no longer demand the justice to the government nor blame the government (external locus of control), instead i’m busy affirming my will to power a.k.a self mastery (internal locus of control).

>2) How to Read a Book - Mortimer J. Adler

This book helps me read better. To read a book is to understand a book. To understand a book according to Adler, one needs to:

- Identify its genre and type;
- Identify its common words;
- Identify each definition of the word;
- Identify the relation or causation of every proposition or sentence.

(Note: these are only fragments. To get the whole conception, you need to read the book).

>3) The Power of Habit - Charles Duhigg

This book helps me replace my bad habit into the good ones. According to him, habit is being consisted of cue, routine, and reward. To replace your bad habit into the good habit, you need to find the new routine with the same que and the same reward. For example: i feel bored (que), i smoke cigeratte (routine), and i feel happy (reward). Now i replace it with the good ones. I feel bored (que), i read short story (routine), and i feel happy (reward).

>4) Dhammapada - Buddha

This book tells the fourth noble truth: there is suffering, there is the cause of suffering, there is a ceasation of suffering, and there is a way of ceasation of suffering. When things turned into void, i used remembering this concept and then i felt so much better. However Buddha also teaches the concept of attachment: one feels suffering because he is being too attached by the material things, and the ideas of past and future. To combat this, one needs to have pure consciousness (a total awareness of the present moment) by practicing meditation.

>5) How to Get Out of Friend Zone: Turn Your Friendship into a Relationship - Jet & Star

This book helped me getting a girlfriend. The authors of this book told me that to get a girlfriend, one needs to have a realization that romantic relationship is power dynamics. This means don’t give too much power too your crush. Things to avoid according to this book:

- Don’t give too many compliments;
- Don’t be too romantic;
- Don’t say “yes” everytime.

Things to do according to this book:

- Show that you have a hobby to tell;
- Dress respectable (no needs always to be formal); and
- Break the boundary by exercising physical touch to her or him (only when you have gone deeper and got consent verbally or non-verbally). This gives a sign to your crush that you want more than a friendship and also builds affection between you and her/or him.

>>21384332
I enjoyed A Time of Gifts, but it's very obviously a work of fiction. He kept a journal when traveling, but it's very unlikely that he knew and kept track of every architectural detail and every kind of tree while he was busy fighting nazis and fucking girls. He even admits that there were whole lapses in his journal, and he had entirely forgotten entire events, except for one small sentence he scribbled somewhere. That, plus the fact that he wrote the actual book when he was 60 or 70, so none of these details were fresh in his mind. It makes me think that he did a lot of research, looked at a lot of photographs, read history books and visited museums, and drew upon those to supplement his writing.

It was a very entertaining read but not a very authentic one.

>>21384166
There are so many good ones. William T. Vollmann's "The Atlas," while fiction, is heavily informed by in-person research. Louis's already been mentioned. MFK Fisher (aside from writing wonderfully about food) has a book about traveling/eating her way through France that's lovely. Surprised no one's mentioned DH Lawrence's travel writing yet. I don't remember if anyone's collected his travel work into one volume, it might be scattered across his essays, but if you can find it, read it. Patrick Leigh Fermor's worth your time. Bruce Chatwin's "In Patagonia" is a classic of the genre. For some comfy Americana give Steinbeck's "Travels with Charley" a shot. Thoreau's most famous for Walden but his travel writing about the American northeast is just as good, if not better. (Thoreau's an underappreciated stylist.)

>>21383914
Satisfaction can be a death for parts of us. Aspects of our consciousness longer call out from our depths once we've met their needs. But we're used to those aspect of us. We've adapted to their demands. We did the things they demanded of us, and at some point in life they go away.

In your case, a major step like this might have satisfied some parts of yourself that you needed for motivation. My advice is to find other ways to motivate. Instead of (speculating here, but the idea is the point) obeying the idea that it'd be shameful not to read as fuel to motivate to read, or obeying some sense of fear of bad health for motivation to exercise, see if you can find new and healthier prompts. I suppose another word for this is discipline: the ability to do a thing without needing an internal prompt. To develop such discipline, you can do things like cold showers, carrying heavy stuff for X kilometers, jogging for Y minutes. Tasks that are tangible and that have an end point you have to push your way into.

With the power of discipline, you can prompt yourself.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Overall, I found nothing unique in Wolfe. Perhaps it's because I've read quite a bit of odd fantasy; if all I read was mainstream stuff, then I'd surely find Wolfe unpredictable, since he is a step above them. But compared to Leiber, Howard, Dunsany, Eddison, Kipling, Haggard, Peake, Mieville, or Moorcock, Wolfe is nothing special.

Perhaps I just got my hopes up too high. I imagined something that might evoke Peake or Leiber (at his best), perhaps with a complexity and depth gesturing toward Milton or Ariosto. I could hardly imagine a better book than that, but even a book half that good would be a delight--or a book that was nothing like that, but was unpredictable and seductive in some other way.

I kept waiting for something to happen, but it never really did. It all plods along without much rise or fall, just the constant moving action to make us think something interesting is happening. I did find some promise, some moments that I would have loved to see the author explore, particularly those odd moments where Silver Age Sci Fi crept in, but each time he touched upon these, he would return immediately to the smallness of his plot and his annoying prick of a narrator. I never found the book to be difficult or complex, merely tiring. the unusual parts were evasive and vague, and the dull parts constant and repetitive.

The whole structure (or lack of it) does leave things up to interpretation, and perhaps that's what some readers find appealing: that they can superimpose their own thoughts and values onto the narrator, and onto the plot itself. But at that point, they don't like the book Wolfe wrote, they like the book they are writing between his lines.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Then there is the fact that every character you meet in the story turns up again, hundreds of miles away, to reveal that they are someone else and have been secretly controlling the action of the plot. It feels like the entire world is populated by about fifteen people who follow the narrator around wherever he goes. If the next two books continue along the same lines, then the big reveal will be that the world is entirely populated by no more than three superpowered shapeshifters.

Everyone in the book has secret identities, secret connections to grand conspiracies, and important plot elements that they conveniently hide until the last minute, only doling out clues here and there. There are no normal people in this world, only double agents and kings in disguise. Every analysis I've read of this book mentions that even the narrator is unreliable.

This can be an effective technique, but in combination with a world of infinite, unpredictable intrigue, Wolfe's story begins to evoke something between a soap opera and a convoluted mystery novel, relying on impossible and contradictory scenarios to mislead the audience. Apparently, this is the thing his fans most appreciate about him--I find it to be an insulting and artificial game.

I agree with this reviewer that there is simply not enough structure to the story to make the narrator's unreliability meaningful. In order for unreliable narration to be effective, there must be some clear and evident counter-story that undermines it. Without that, it is not possible to determine meaning, because there's nowhere to start: everything is equally shaky.

At that point, it's just a trick--adding complexity to the surface of the story without actually producing any new meaning. I know most sci fi and fantasy authors seem to love complexity for its own sake, but it's a cardinal sin of storytelling: don't add something into your story unless it needs to be there. Covering the story with a lot of vagaries and noise may impress some, but won't stand up to careful reading.

During the years when I earned my living as a teacher of fiction-writing in a university, one or another of my students would sometimes call on me in my office and would claim that she could not write the pieces of fiction that I required her to write and would give as the reason for this that she did not understand what I meant by the word fiction. I used the words her and she in the previous sentence only because three-quarters of my students of fiction-writing were females.

While I was writing the previous sentence, I saw in my mind an image of the view from the chair that I used as my chair in one of the rooms that I used as my office during the years when I was a teacher in a university. The view was of part of the room as it would have appeared to me if ever I had been visited in my office by a certain young woman who was one of my students for two years but never visited me during those years. The young woman never visited me or asked me to explain what I meant by the word fiction, but she wrote as the last of her assignments while she was my student a piece of fiction that earned from me the highest numerical mark on a scale of 1 to 100 that I gave to any piece of fiction during the years mentioned above.

While I was writing the previous paragraph, I understood that the young woman mentioned there was listening to the words of a man who was talking about the writing of fiction. I could not see any image of the man, and I could not hear in my mind any words that the man was speaking, but I understood that the man was in the room and that the young woman was listening to the words of the man. I understood these things in the same way that I understand many of the matters that I seem afterwards to have seen and to have heard while dreaming.

While I was writing the previous paragraph, I understood that the young woman mentioned there could not hear any words from the man mentioned there but that she was aware of what the man could well have spoken to her in the same way that I am aware of what could well have been spoken to me by images of persons that I seem afterwards to have been aware of while dreaming.

There were some countries so far from this city and so little spoken of among my acquaintances that no one objected when I summed up their terrain or their people in a few words. Nor did I object when I found equally brief descriptions of the same countries in reviews of books I would never read or in magazines I would never subscribe to.

*****

I kept to myself some of my interpretations of its forbidding architecture, the awkward restraint of its dances, and the provoking fluidity of its language. And few people had the opportunity to dispute my explanations for the decline of some dynasty or the relentless persecution of some wayward sect.

But I never doubted the existence of the land, even when I least expected to learn where it lay. Whenever I was assured that it could not be located beyond this or that frontier, I only intensified my researches into its culture. I even surmised that some traveller had already uncovered in an actual territory the way of life that I knew as necessary to some nameless folk, but that his account of his travels had been suppressed or hopelessly mutilated.

*****

On the steep side of a mountain, in the country that I first found in those days, a ragged shepherd sprawled beside his flock. He was able to watch all day the comings and goings of villagers among the huddled houses across the narrow valley. But he himself lay almost unnoticed among the lowest reaches of a dense forest. In the languid hours of afternoon, the men and women moving in and out of his field of vision were mere blurs of limbs propelled by the same insistent energies that drove the wind through the branches above him or brought his snuffling sheep to the very grass where his legs rested.

The thoughts that occurred to this man might have seemed outrageous to anyone but myself. I had watched many a distant village in sombre illustrations and seen their inhabitants stripped of the invisible but bulky layers of moral fabric that I sensed about the people nearer me. The face of the man was haggard and creased. I knew he had done in his native valley what I would not have failed to do between far hillsides. And years before I knew that his homeland was called Romania, I called it, for convenience, Romania.

A group of farm-workers straightened their backs and rested for a moment from their threshing. Women and men stood elbow to elbow. The drudgery of their work in the shadeless sunlit field and the nearness of the keen-eyed older women should have protected the only girl I was interested in. And even though she looked willingly into the eyes of some passing traveller with a camera, the folds of the white shawl hiding half her face should have proved that she held herself aloof from the stocky scowling men around her. But I could devise only one explanation for the troubled expression that marred her delicate features. Young as she was, she had been besmirched already by the ruling vice of her race.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21382501
I like how he writes about experience. It is direct and delivered in such simple rhythmic prose. In a way Murnane is trying to write what cannot be written. What you feel for a certain character or at a certain image, with the barest glimpse in the text, conjured in a few lines of prose that affects you greatly but cannot be rationally explained in language. He is trying to write how our internal lives are lived exactly instead of just narrating them as a stream of intelligible thought (stream of consciousness; a little nonsensical since most of our inner world is non-verbal). The weirdness in his work is a function of our own inability to explain the workings of our involuntary imagination or memory.

His theory of prose and fiction is very nice, but I can do without. He started leaning into his idiosyncracies too much. So much so that his later work will be better regarded by writers of fiction than sensitive readers. Inland is the high watermark and hits the sweet spot perfectly. It is genuinely one of the best books written post-war.

The 1st paragraph in this post is my impression of his work, but I must clarify that it is an impression of an impression for my impression is both the premise and inspiration for the book, as revealed in the last few pages, that is in the background of this discussion: Inland.

I liked it for two main reasons: the first one that it happens to be about the best analytic study of Qualia in fiction. The second for the imagination at work. He didn't only have to imagine a premise (a sect of plainsmen in some inner region of Australia) but also how their minds, their myths would work. It takes unexpected but sensible turns and in turn reveals how our own minds take and interpret lived experiences. The plainsmen are become outsiders we can view from beyond the glass and see our minds reflected.
If a Borges wroye a novel this is what would come out. Except Murnane is a genius on Borges' level so it never feels like an imitation.

>>21384390
It was extremely influential and made Junger a celebrity and public intellectual for 20 years, Junger was felt to have captured the zeitgeist and the collective unconscious of the "front generation" (the men who came back and often fought as Freikorps, joined stuff like Stahlhelm, etc.). This generation and these movements are often considered one of the leading reasons Weimar fell because of their peculiar mixture of resentment (at the old government that betrayed their efforts by capitulating, and at the new government for trying to forget the past and pretend Germany was always some parliamentary democracy), their disillusionment with modernity and war trauma, and their readiness to act and soldierly "me ne frego" willingness to gamble everything on heroism rather than live as vanquished eunuchs. At first these things channeled into various radical thought currents like the National Revolutionaries (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conservative_Revolution#National_revolutionaries ) and National Bolshevism (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernst_Niekisch ) but these movements failed to achieve the anti-Weimar revolution they wanted, and instead the atmosphere of anti-Weimarism they contributed to made the NSDAP's seizure of power in 1933 plausible to average Germans.

Roger Woods has good books on it and Junger specifically.

You have the general location and you have the level of technology and such. You have an outsketch of a place you can see in your mind. Now: What is your genre beyond speculative adventure fiction? Do you want it to be a black-comedy, you want a swashbuckling romance, do you want to attack or defend some sort of principle or idea which you will hook into your themes, or are you just looking for a good time with a clear conclusion and no mystery to the reader left unsolved at the end? This will help guide you in the 'tone' that your first chapters take, which will inevitably lead you to tonal shifts as you move through the acts of the story.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>John Dryden (1631 – 1700) was an English poet, literary critic, translator, and playwright who was appointed England's first Poet Laureate in 1668. He is seen as dominating the literary life of Restoration England to such a point that the period came to be known in literary circles as the Age of Dryden. Romanticist writer Sir Walter Scott called him "Glorious John".
>Dryden was the dominant literary figure and influence of his age. He established the heroic couplet as a standard form of English poetry by writing successful satires, religious pieces, fables, epigrams, compliments, prologues, and plays with it; he also introduced the alexandrine and triplet into the form. In his poems, translations, and criticism, he established a poetic diction appropriate to the heroic couplet—Auden referred to him as "the master of the middle style"—that was a model for his contemporaries and for much of the 18th century. The considerable loss felt by the English literary community at his death was evident in the elegies written about him. Dryden's heroic couplet became the dominant poetic form of the 18th century. Alexander Pope was heavily influenced by Dryden and often borrowed from him; other writers were equally influenced by Dryden and Pope. Pope famously praised Dryden's versification in his imitation of Horace's Epistle II.i: "Dryden taught to join / The varying pause, the full resounding line, / The long majestic march, and energy divine." Samuel Johnson[25] summed up the general attitude with his remark that "the veneration with which his name is pronounced by every cultivator of English literature, is paid to him as he refined the language, improved the sentiments, and tuned the numbers of English poetry." His poems were very widely read, and are often quoted, for instance, in Henry Fielding's Tom Jones and Johnson's essays.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.sub: Lady of the Lake: Battle of Brenna
posts.com:
I personally thought this battle was a great example of what makes Sapkowski's writing so special. He manages to make a battle- an event seen all the time in fantasy writing- and make it something incredibly unique and special. The way he switches up points of view and narration give us a comprehensive view of the battle while maintaining an interesting and powerful human element in something so large and chaotic. The perspectives of the generals, the scouts, the messengers, and the foot-soldiers are all considered, and he reveals glimpses into the future as people consider Brenna as a historical event. He blends present and future masterfully in narration- we see many different parts of the battle from many different perspectives but he makes it all flow seamlessly. One passage is set in a Nilfgaardian military academy years after the Battle of Brenna and is told almost entirely through dialogue. This passage nonetheless meshes perfectly with the next passage- told in third person narration from the perspective of a mercenary at the Battle of Brenna. Sapkowski's brilliant cast of more minor characters really shine during this battle, making it compelling and meaningful on a personal level as well as it's significance in regards to the war. Jarre, Shani, Dennis Cranmer, Yarpen Zigrin, Coen, and more characters from previous books end up at Brenna for some reason or another, and combine to tell a compelling tale totally bereft of the major characters of the series but nonetheless a testament to the fantastic characters of this series. Sapkowski's ability to weave interesting and engaging life stories with sometimes heartbreaking endings into a battle scene is incredible, and I feel like words are failing me as I try to describe all the amazing things Sapkowski does with his writing in this scene. Learning the fates of those who survived the battle is also so melancholy- some characters get to live happily while others end up meeting with misfortune. I have read series where the deaths of major characters don't effect me at all, but learning about the ends of some of the characters who survived Brenna was tough, although also another example of Sapkowki's excellent writing. I would love to delve further into some of the fascinating scenes of this battle but then I would never wrap this post up. Throughout his telling of the Battle of Brenna Sapkowski mixed battlefield tactics with the more visceral parts of the human experience. Hope and despair, loyalty and fear, bravery and cowardice. All this framed with exceptionally clever narration choices, interspersed with dark and ironic humor throughout, creates what is in my opinion one of the most complex and original examples of storytelling there is.

TL;DR This section of the books was one of my favorites as it really demonstrates the strength of Sapkowski's writing and the depth of his characters.

>>21383514
The appeal of the Bible isn't that it was written by God or something, it's that the authors of the sixty-six different books all hailed from different time periods, different professions, different cultures, and all their writings compiled together tell an incredibly grand and nuanced narrative that spans centuries.

The Old Testament was mostly written by David, Solomon, Moses, and various minor prophets, and it's full of prophesies that came true hundreds of years later during the events of the new testament; and like how Don Quixote part two makes meta-references to part one, the people alive in the time of Jesus were familiar with the old testament, not knowing or suspecting that they would become historical figures in the new testament one day, and their stories are personal and harrowing.

The Bible also tells us that God guided the hands the wrote it, so while each book has a different writing style depending on the author, they were all moved to write by God.

For example, Paul was the most prolific and productive of the apostles, while Luke was a doctor with a lot of attention to detail--so when reading their respective books and epistles, we see that Paul's is full of more passion while Luke gives a much more detailed account than most of the other apostles--but each one shares their own point of view and experience with Jesus.

The fact that the books in the Bible are written by men works in its favor, not against it. There's something about reading Paul's letters that he wrote to the churches while being stoned, beaten, and thrown in prison for years at a time that inspires awe. And who can forget Peter, who was a foul-mouthed fisherman until Jesus came along, and then he betrayed Jesus, only to become one of his most ardent apostles? And pretty much all of the apostles became martyrs. Paul was beheaded, John the Baptist had his head cut off in prison and brought to a woman on a plate, and Peter was crucified upside down, because he said he didn't deserve to be crucified the same way Jesus was.

Contemporary Philosophy departments are trash. The people working on continental philosophy in them are teaching barely recognizable skewed versions of them, like analytic phenomenology which is an embarrassment, or they are the one token guy who reads Heidegger, but he's also forced to be conversant with the analytic tradition, which as we all know is mental poison. The few exceptions to the rule tend to be at colleges with strong Catholic or evangelical backgrounds.

>the neoliberal consensus, where no such phenomenon exists in philosophy
Exactly the same phenomenon exists. Analytic philosophy was notorious for being a tyrannical gatekeeper for generations. It forced certain methods and perspectives on students. Even nowadays, when this bias is less overt, it's still present everywhere because of the permanent damage it did to the people who studied under its overt form. Luckily analytic philosophy is a dying paradigm, as many older professors in the tradition constantly lament, but it will take another generation at least for it to die completely. It's a slow death, as the bonafide analytic outlook is finally just being absorbed by STEMshit and computer science from one side, and as more and more continental-adjacent approaches seep into Philosophy departments from the other side as you noted. But it's still an awful environment to work in if you love philosophy.

>>21385603
Well if you get into a program you're going to have to move and be in residence for at least 2-4 years, that is, until you're ABD. That's bare minimum, because it's simply not feasible in my experience to skip town as soon as your coursework is over and try to do everything over Zoom. Also, you're old enough and have presumably been out of university long enough that it may be hard to get into a top program, because top programs look at you as an investment (you boost their reputation, they get more promising applicants), and only take a limited number of students. To get in you need to have very good letters of recommendation ideally from professors who present you as a "get" for the department, not just as a smart guy from 5 years ago, if they even remember you enough to say something distinct. In Philosophy especially I think there is a concern for poaching students who are obviously plugged into hot or soon to be hot trends, maybe slightly more so than in other disciplines, because Philosophy "moves" in trends and schools and figures associated with them. If you are a generalist whose application will sound more like "Ever since I was a lad I've always loved philosophy" than like "I worked with Professor Grant on this project in the philosophy of computing, and I'm pitching this hot sounding project on neural nets or whatever is hot right now," even with a perfect GPA I suspect you may struggle to get into top programs.

Also, there's a sea change underway in how graduate programs are run from what I can tell, for example programs are forcing people through more quickly along more regularized tracks, focusing on "professionalization" more than humanistic generalism. There's talk about how the good/bad old days of people finishing in 12 years are over, and now the administration wants much more oversight and regularity in the process. Remember this is coupled with the ongoing retirement of older professors, and their replacement by "up and coming" late gen-x'ers and early millennials, where "up and coming" is defined by the standards of the current liberal consensus, so, often but not always, woke networking by oversocialized drones. The old professors who remember the golden era of rubber stamping and smaller admin are leaving, and the new professors who have only known the days of bloated admin and cutthroat networking and trend-chasing are arriving. Also it seems to be generally acknowledged that graduate student quality has dropped horribly, so there is a kind of fatalism about the professionalization and routinization because if everyone sucks and is generic anyway, you might as well flay them into shape.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>21385705
Have you looked at what the best case scenario is after you get the PhD? Even the luckiest and most brilliant graduates will probably do a postdoc or adjunct, or a tenure track job at a less prestigious institution, with salaries in the mid five figures for most postdocs and adjuncts and still not great for tenure track. And you also don't control where you get a position, so you will once again probably have to move and start over, now 35-40 minimum. If it's a postdoc or adjunct position, this is all so you can just restart the process and move again wherever your next position is. If it's tenure track, you'll still be hunting for a higher prestige/pay job, and likely have to move again. Once your PhD is done you will still be slogging to publish and stay relevant for a couple more years, while also hunting for these jobs and moving as necessary. Again, this is all if you do quite well by current market standards, with a PhD from a top tier uni, and even in this case you may end up only finding a permanent six figure position in your very late 30s or early 40s.

Assume every thing I said here is completely wrong because I'm a random idiot on the internet and I'm not in Philosophy but an adjacent field anyway. But hopefully you're at least getting a picture of what it can be like. All this so you can make, what, mid-100k, teaching increasingly stupid high schoolers intro to logic? If you have your own home and mortgage paid off by 30 you're a lucky bastard, you have a lot more freedom than most. I would seriously consider aiming at retiring early or living off passive income and just studying philosophy on the side.

However the one thing that formal institutional study can do is force you to keep your head in it. If you decide now that you will just study for fun, there's a 90% chance you will never really study anything, because autodidactism is a license to slack off. Most independent scholars are hacks and for every hack independent scholar there are 1000 "independent scholars" who never did anything but make vague plans. Read Confederacy of Dunces and set Ignatius Reilly up as an archetype in your mind. I can say with absolute confidence I never would have gained expert knowledge of anything, finished any project, or really unlocked my potential unless I had gone through the worthless piece of shit gauntlet that is a doctorate. Take the average autist who wants to learn Japanese, and follow his life trajectory through two alternate universes: one where he got a PhD and hates himself and regrets ruining his life getting it, and another where he didn't get the PhD and made six figures as a welder and studied Japanese in his free time. 95 times out of 100, the PhD guy who hates his life at least fucking knows Japanese. (But then forgets it in two years after completing his PhD and never touching it again.)

Life is complicated. The most you can do is know the stakes and take your best shot.

That's my general feeling too but I want to re-emphasize the Japanese example I gave, and what I said about how I would never be the person I am today and be blessed with the interests and knowledge I have, if I had gone the autodidact route. I know exactly what I would have done, because I still do it: I would daydream for years and have all these intentions, and never do anything, or only ever do 5% of it, because there's always next month, next year, this weekend. The only reason I grew and actually developed my skills and interests is because I was forced to, by one absolutely pointless deadline or another. This still happens on a regular basis, I pile up a bunch of "oh yeah I'll definitely have that project underway or done this year," and I don't do shit but daydream for 10 months, and then the responsibility I signed up for forces me to actually do it because I'll be shamed or fired otherwise.

If by some miracle you can impose these strictures on yourself without external compulsion, then I agree that academia has nothing to offer you. But I know for a fact that I would have stagnated if I hadn't been forced through the gauntlet, and forced to rebel against it partly out of spite. I hate academia but at least it forced me to keep studying Japanese every day. Then again this probably only applies to autists, and has very little to do with the program itself. All of your peers will still be professionalized mediocrities with no passion for the subject.

If some other institution could provide this compulsion, academia would have no value. Seriously, if you are reading this and you are a typical /lit/ autodidact or aspiring autodidact, with intentions to publish or contribute to some philosophical discourse or whatever, start giving yourself real deadlines SOMEHOW, or I promise you'll never do anything. Even if it's just the embarrassment of a journal editor expecting your submission and sending you increasingly irate emails, putting that fear of God into you because on a purely animal level you don't want to have to send a sheepish "I never did it, sorry lol" reply. Even if your goal is to make the next Dwarf Fortress game, you need something external that continuously forces you to produce results for years on end or you will never do shit, especially in this era where everybody we're all spaced out, spoiled excuse-makers and "gifted underachievers."

Right now I'm preparing for a brief interview in a month about some topic the person thinks I'm an expert on, and while I theoretically am, I am so scared by the prospect of looking like a dumbass that I am re-reading the entire corpus on that thing, and having a good time. And this is having the side benefit of kicking me back into gear for a project I wanted to write on this topic. Why didn't I do this for the last 5 years of being an "expert" and intending to write that project? Because I don't do shit unless I'll be embarrassed otherwise. Intentions mean fucking nothing.

I want to work in academia, but only because I cannot possible think about living without researching and teaching. The truth is, I love writing about literature, and talking about literature with people who love it as much as I do - even if I am being paid pennies.

The general advice I can give, is to not work in academia unless it's the only possible thing you could do. Almost every other field is more profitable than academy, let alone in humanities.
If you are in the US, I extremely advice against pursuing education in (most) humanities. We don't have to pay for university where I live, and this is the main reason, I think, I decided to study humanities. Had I no chance but to take a loan to pay it, I would have gone to a stem degree first.

What are your other options? If you decide to stay in academia, doing a PhD in another area close to your philosophical interests may be worthwhile. Many great philosophers were, in fact, not philosophy graduates. Kripke only did an undergraduate in mathematics, Kuhn was a physicist, Wittgenstein was an engineer, and many others had similar stories. Often the experience of someone from a different field can bring a new vision to a philosophical problem.

>smith tried to provide evidence for his bullshit and it fell apart because people could see that it was horseshit.
I've seen other people point this out for other parts of Mormonism. The Mormons tried to drop the Greek-inherited philosophical speculation and obscurantism in favor of "common sense" truth, and it bit them in the ass. The philosophical obscurantism lets you cloak bizarre and insane stuff in an air of reason and mysticism, and the ass-pull of personal revelation means that all cards are on the table (you either trust it 100% or you don't, either way you are convinced of something).

"The bread turns into Jesus's severed muscles and we eat it" is stupid, but "Transubstantiation" is deep and mystical; "God has a wife on the planet Kolob" is retarded, but if it was "sovereign dominionistic theosis" it would be some kind of high-level philosophical doctrine.

>>21383608
I was thinking about the eternal recurrence recently and entropy is exactly what I thought of as well, so I went down a rabbit hole. Entropy generally is always increasing, so time has a direction, but it is possible to decrease entropy (via "quantum fluctuations" or something) on a small scale. So if we go forward in time to the "heat death" (maximum entropy), and maybe we get lucky and the expansion of universe reverses and we get a "big crunch", so all matter is ultimately re-condensed in an infinitesimally small volume, which sounds like it would be an extreme sort of way to reduce entropy to a minimum, from which we get another big bang, and the cycle repeats. Question would be whether or not the universe can contract back; current observations are only that it's expanding and accelerating, not decelerating, but that doesn't say anything about whether or not it could reverse course some time in the future. Fun thought experiment, anyway.

It's vague because I'm not a theoretical physicist. As far as I know, nobody knows the physics by which the universe's expansion could be reversed, so it's just a thought experiment. I read this book when I was recovering from transplant. To me it was overrated trash, but I still remember this physician being very upset by the fact that I would read such a "dark book". To me Raskolnikov was basically a guy too dumb to be an engineer or public servant so he buried himself in this last hope kind of effort to be a literary genius. But you have to do literary things, don't you? He's out proving how smart he is, kills a guy, and then meets this copper who makes him look like a total midwit. He goes down for the crime, they put him in a heavy labor sentence, and he's cool with it because this naive pretty girl will be waiting for him. But being the pseud that he was, he pretended God's wisdom would allow him to endure his rightly earned sentence. What's so good about that other than the vulgar townspeople doing the obnoxious thing in the streets and making drama just so someone would pay attention to them. I mean, who gives a care in 2022 about such a story? I was entirely bemused by it and a little pissed that he made a big deal out of nothing. Since then whenever the novel comes up I usually say the same thing: Seems like more of a young man's book. I didn't get much out of it.

Literature has always been a pastime for a minority, especially when most people were illiterate, and people have always regarded it as impractical. If you're reading literature for self-improvement, if it feels like a chore to you, then yeah you're better off doing something else. posts.com:
The Prince paced back and forth in his room. His father gave him a mission — one that he did not know how to accomplish. He was almost sixteen years of age and needed to wed. The princesses of the nearby kingdoms were too old or he did not find them to be suitable in one way or another. He could not possibly marry a commoner, that would be against the rules of the kingdom.
“What to do?” he bemoaned, “perhaps a bit of fresh air would be for the best.” Taking his horn, he blew a bellowing cry for his steed; a Dragon given to him by his godfather, the Wizard of Pillarime.
A gust of wind and a loud thud could be heard on his balcony. The large red dragon knelt in front of the prince, knowing what was desired. Securly mounted, the two took flight across the kingdom of Pillarme. They flew past the forests and into the mountains, finally landing near a large secluded lake surrounded by the snowy peaks that guarded it. It was their spot, a spot no one else knew, except one other; a girl of ashen hair and hazel eyes. She was drinking from the lake undisturbed nor worried about the man and beast in front of her.
“Who are you?” asked the Prince, “I’ve never met another person here. How did you get up here?”
“My name is Meredith. Don’t tell anyone but I used magic.”
“Magic?”
“Yes, magic. Let me show you.”
With a wave of her hand, sparks of mana took shape. She performed for the Prince, dazzling his mind with the beauty she conjured.
“Wow! How did you learn to use magic? And can I do it too?”
Meredith smiled at the Prince. Her eyes welled with tears and her smiling lips drooped into a frown.
“It is a curse which I would never wish upon another. To mock Nature is a crime upon itself.”
“I wish to learn anyways. A talent this powerful could never be a curse. I’ll do anything to be able to cast magic!”
“Are you prepared to sacrifice what you love?”
“Yes!”
Meredith’s eyes glowed a yellow that shocked the dragon. The beast stepped back and arched his neck. Smoke formed from its nostrils, and in a single instant it blew a fire directly at the girl.
“Draco! Stop!” the Prince cried. He turned to Meredith. She was still there, unburnt, and unharmed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21381237
The dragon flapped its wings, ready to take flight, but chains of mana sealed its fate. Binding the beast to the ground, Meredith inched closer to the struggling animal. It leered over to the Prince, whimpering and pleading for any help it could get, but it was too late. Meredith touched the nose of the beast and in an instant, decay set upon its body. The Prince was shocked; speechless at the events that took place. Meredith turned around and held in her hand, a glowing blue orb.
“Here. This is your gift for defying Nature.”
“Where did Draco go? What did you do to him?” cried the Prince.
Without warning, Meredith pressed the glowing orb into the Prince’s chest. Screams of pain erupted in the middle of the mountains, where only one other could hear. The Prince blacked out.
Upon waking, he felt a surge of power in his veins. Looking into the lake, the reflection showed another. A creature with blue eyes and a haggard face. It touched itself, trying to find any comfort in its appearance. Terror turned into laughter, and with it, the monster made a vow to the heavens.
“Meredith! Upon Draco’s grave, even if it takes me ten-thousand years, I will find you!”

>So is it not smart to post your work here for critique if you're actively trying to publish said work?
There are many, many other better venues to share your writing for critique. What you get here are anonymous crabs that are barely competent themselves who shitpost with impunity. They don't care about writing, not yours and not their own. They don't even read. The only reason to post here is because your work is so transgressive (uses the gamer word liberally, is fetish bait, or is thinly veiled /pol/ bait) that it would get you banned on other sites. But if you're writing crap like that, you're not aiming to get published anyway.

I know of at least one website (critters.org) where published authors will sometimes post work and offer critique. The work posted there is not always good, but always demonstrates the writer's best effort. The critiques are also numerous, detailed and generally useful (because there are strict guidelines on how to actually offer critique that everyone has to follow). I know there's some people in these threads that have deluded themselves into thinking that because its given anonymously, the critique is more "honest". It really doesn't matter if critique is honest or not, what matters is if its useful. And critique is really only useful when taken in the aggregate. The bottom line is there aren't enough critics acting in good faith in these threads. It's just too easy to write "stopped reading here" or "complete nonsense" and move on.

>>21384323
It's an interesting premise but the sexual aspects of it undercut it instead of enhancing it. It doesn't need to be so crude - the crudity is not profound and it's not any more illustrative of the autismo mind of the protagonist than his general autismo-ness.

Mentioning specific policies makes this look more like authorial diatribe than a standalone work, so you'd do better to leave that vague. Even if it's not authorial diatribe, and I don't think it is, it feels enough like it could be to be sickening.

There are a couple of moments that wrench me out of the writing a bit. For example, I can't take the name Asher Lockman seriously; it sounds too edgy, even though it's a real-enough name. The sentence "there were goofy mechanical rubber hands that removed her clothes, sort of like the famous contraption from Wallace and Gromit." needs to stop at the comma; goofy mechanical rubber hands is enough, and insisting that the reader imagine exactly the thing from that TV show that one time is... too insistent. The further crudity at this point is again undermining the writing.

The tweest at the end is good and I like it, but it doesn't seem fully developed. The crudity makes more sense when you get the tweest but the problem is that the crudity just feels crude until you make it that far. It would be better if it felt sinister - instead of making the reader feel like he's reading someone's bad erotic fiction you want him to feel like he's reading a well-written horror story about a woman who is trapped in someone's bad erotic fantasy; you want it to read sinister instead of reading crude. As for the "point" that Asher makes, it's fine to make it so briefly but only if the rest of the work is adding context to it. You want the "point" to tie together all of the "evidence" that your story has presented in a lightbulb moment. As I read it your story only contains a point in that single sentence and the rest of it is an entirely separate train.

The fourth-wall "imagine what you want" breaks seem to come out of nowhere and add nothing while being distracting, I'd drop them but if you don't want to then develop them into something more than throwaways.

In short the writing is mechanically competent and the premise and idea is interesting. The delivery was good enough that I actually read the whole thing which is something I almost never do in this threads. It's just not "fully realised", in my view - it doesn't strike the right tone for me and the argument is not expressed with force or impact or clarity. If you made it more sinister and 'erotic' while being less crude and developed the point throughout the whole story (subtly) then it would be closer to complete.

These are just some thoughts and opinions that came to me while I was in my underpants drinking warm Coca Cola from a can that has been on my computer desk overnight.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Overall, I found nothing unique in Wolfe. Perhaps it's because I've read quite a bit of odd fantasy; if all I read was mainstream stuff, then I'd surely find Wolfe unpredictable, since he is a step above them. But compared to Leiber, Howard, Dunsany, Eddison, Kipling, Haggard, Peake, Mieville, or Moorcock, Wolfe is nothing special.

Perhaps I just got my hopes up too high. I imagined something that might evoke Peake or Leiber (at his best), perhaps with a complexity and depth gesturing toward Milton or Ariosto. I could hardly imagine a better book than that, but even a book half that good would be a delight--or a book that was nothing like that, but was unpredictable and seductive in some other way.

I kept waiting for something to happen, but it never really did. It all plods along without much rise or fall, just the constant moving action to make us think something interesting is happening. I did find some promise, some moments that I would have loved to see the author explore, particularly those odd moments where Silver Age Sci Fi crept in, but each time he touched upon these, he would return immediately to the smallness of his plot and his annoying prick of a narrator. I never found the book to be difficult or complex, merely tiring. the unusual parts were evasive and vague, and the dull parts constant and repetitive.

The whole structure (or lack of it) does leave things up to interpretation, and perhaps that's what some readers find appealing: that they can superimpose their own thoughts and values onto the narrator, and onto the plot itself. But at that point, they don't like the book Wolfe wrote, they like the book they are writing between his lines.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21380033
Then there is the fact that every character you meet in the story turns up again, hundreds of miles away, to reveal that they are someone else and have been secretly controlling the action of the plot. It feels like the entire world is populated by about fifteen people who follow the narrator around wherever he goes. If the next two books continue along the same lines, then the big reveal will be that the world is entirely populated by no more than three superpowered shapeshifters.

Everyone in the book has secret identities, secret connections to grand conspiracies, and important plot elements that they conveniently hide until the last minute, only doling out clues here and there. There are no normal people in this world, only double agents and kings in disguise. Every analysis I've read of this book mentions that even the narrator is unreliable.

This can be an effective technique, but in combination with a world of infinite, unpredictable intrigue, Wolfe's story begins to evoke something between a soap opera and a convoluted mystery novel, relying on impossible and contradictory scenarios to mislead the audience. Apparently, this is the thing his fans most appreciate about him--I find it to be an insulting and artificial game.

I agree with this reviewer that there is simply not enough structure to the story to make the narrator's unreliability meaningful. In order for unreliable narration to be effective, there must be some clear and evident counter-story that undermines it. Without that, it is not possible to determine meaning, because there's nowhere to start: everything is equally shaky.

At that point, it's just a trick--adding complexity to the surface of the story without actually producing any new meaning. I know most sci fi and fantasy authors seem to love complexity for its own sake, but it's a cardinal sin of storytelling: don't add something into your story unless it needs to be there. Covering the story with a lot of vagaries and noise may impress some, but won't stand up to careful reading.

It's just an oversaturated world. To judge it by early 20th century standards is unfair.

posts.name: Anonymous

>it’s an art form because it invokes aesthetic sensibility through imagery, prosaic or metrical rhythm, as well as tone and atmosphere
yes, but that doesn't mean it is strictly art. the sensibilities of what is evocative is subject dependant. a work of literature which lacks the aesthetic sensibilities of its creator is not art on account of its lack of aesthetic value to its maker. this is the point we ask whether it is the observer or the creator of art which determines its merit as 'art,' to which i'd conclude that it comes down to the creator. it comes down to the creator because he is the actor, the one who discriminates over what to include or exclude and why, that forms the material provided into its shape; whether he makes something of function which is absent of his aesthetic sense or something that reflects his aesthetic sense is not a matter of serendipity--it is done by deliberate choice. likewise, an object whose materials were thrown together by no volition of its making does not deserve the title of art as it reflects no intent of creation. it may well be deemed beautiful, like nature, but it does not become art. (note: this does not negate realism as an art form, but it does negate photography as art as it is documentary in nature; parenthetically, the discerning capture of an artist-photographer does, paradoxically, make it art since it is marked by discrimination of the actor choosing his shots.)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It is a subset of art.
More specifically, it is the sort of art whose primary medium is natural language (written or spoken).
Defining art in general is an another matter, and under pretty much all normal definitions of art literature counts as an art form.
I understand art as a form of semantically rich communication, above that of a natural language in practical use - both in its details (e.g. otherwise trivial word choice can become one of the central tools of meaning-making, whereas in everyday communication you could switch two synonymous words and lose nothing) and in its overall meaning (art relates to human experience as widely as possible, opening (itself to) many perspectives, whereas in everyday communication we describe and point to specific, single objects and meanings). A poem should be read a dozen times, a text message only once.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>21383738
Life isn't a box of chocolates but it's not sincity either. It's cultural standards. Times have changed. We're not a bunch of superstitious peasants farming potatoes. Just because something occurred sometime in the past, doesn't mean that it's timely or relevant now. We want stories more complex than some jacked demigod killing a hydra, and we have some standards about what is and isn't appropriate for goofy kids' stories. In a modern environment, kids are going to be exposed to the fact that there are terrible things happening in the world either way. The argument also ignores that they have a limited effect. Even if a fairy tale gives someone a basic idea of death, it's still gonna hit hard when their loved one dies for real. Regardless of how many gritty stories they've read, because experiencing something by yourself is always different than just being a passive observer to a fictional scenario. I know you're gonna reply with some vague slogan like "oh but reading these stories is gonna make them more prepared", but that is an extremely moot and vague notion that also leads me to my next point: there are so much more factors influencing how a person grows up than the culture they consume. It's also about their parents, their peers, their upbringing, their social environment. It's possible for one to have never read a single Grimm brothers story but have seen some horrendous shit as a kid.

>The beauty and horror of The Juniper Tree (Von dem Machandelboom), with its exquisite and tragic beginning, the abominable cannibal stew, the gruesome bones, the gay and vengeful bird-spirit coming out of a mist that rose from the tree, has remained with me since childhood; and yet always the chief flavour of that tale lingering in the memory was not beauty or horror, but distance and a great abyss of time, not measurable even by twe tusend Johr. Without the stew and the bones— which children are now too often spared in mollified versions of Grimm —that vision would largely have been lost. I do not think I was harmed by the horror in the fairytale setting, out of whatever dark beliefs and practices of the past it may have come. Such stories have now a mythical or total (unanalysable) effect, an effect quite independent of the findings of Comparative Folklore, and one which it cannot spoil or explain; they open a door on Other Time, and if we pass through, though only for a moment, we stand outside our own time, outside Time itself, maybe.

More Tolkien:
>The consolation of fairy-stories, the joy of the happy ending: or more correctly of the good catastrophe, the sudden joyous “turn” (for there is no true end to any fairy-tale): this joy, which is one of the things which fairy-stories can produce supremely well, is not essentially “escapist,” nor “fugitive.” In its fairy-tale—or otherworld—setting, it is a sudden and miraculous grace: never to be counted on to recur. It does not deny the existence of dyscatastrophe, of sorrow and failure: the possibility of these is necessary to the joy of deliverance; it denies (in the face of much evidence, if you will) universal final defeat and in so far is evangelium, giving a fleeting glimpse of Joy, Joy beyond the walls of the world, poignant as grief.

I think the question of transsexualism is a question of psychological well being. As with all mental pathology, it's expression is highly influenced by culture.

Ofcourse, not all cultures are same, as not all mechanisms of repression are the same. Therefore, different pathologies get expressed at inproportionate rates across the globe.

>>21385311
I think it's mostly a psychotherapeutic idea that stems from a read on Nietzsche. Irvin Yalom talks about it a lot in his books, but basically it stems from the notion of ubermensch and the overcoming of the self - the self the subject has created to orient themselves in the world or the lacanian "I".
It is a slave of definitions and labels, and language itself, by consisting of what can be captured within the confines of language as this "self" only really exists when observed and by negation of identity (as in, I'm not Chad and therefore i exist as a seperate entitiy - and Chad is not me.)

The subject, on the other hand, is repressed and never expressed other in what some may call "divine experiences". In fact, these experiences are when one has overcome their self and become what the Ubermensch is. Therapeutically, it means shedding the skin that is the self and enlarging ones repertoire in behavior, emotional reactions etc and even escaping the trap of negation. Ultimately The subject isn't concerned with forming a "true" identity, only a sufficient one that matches the outside worlds demand - be it by forming hypercompetitiveness and denying it's own desires or developing gender dysphoria as a means to cope with the fact that identity is a constructed spook. The "true" identity would be an identity that is only concerned with the threats that face the subject, and by extension would be a subject incapable of action.
It borders on essentialism, but i still wouldn't say it is. as the subject is seen as fractured and a process rather than a static core. It changes through time, and morphs to react to repressed and unconscious desires, while also having conflicting fragments of itself.

Not sure if this made anymore sense, i have to admit that a large part is my own thinking so it's doomed to be filled with inconsistencies.

Every human soul is a hole;

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21384774
Well said. I feel Solzhenitsyn manages to navigate profound topics of discussion really naturally (without appearing pretentious or contriving) by paying great attention to character interplay. I feel he makes sure all of the characters not only have an intellectual history and catalogue of culture (as real people do) and varying levels of intelligence/types of expression. I love that in the titular Cancer Ward, the patients are able to discuss the “purpose and meaning of life” by having a very upfront and about discussion What Men Live By. And when Solzhenitsyn does revert to direct ideation, he adds a dash of surrealism to blend the dumping of information better (like when the owl-eyed fellow rants to Kostloglotov about idols of the marketplace). Another aspect I loved in the novel was his ability to transition from highly realistic segments to surreality in split moments of crisis or sickness without any undue warning.

I'll try to put it as simply: one finds things like the zombie Psyduck or Shadow the Hedgehog using guns while mildly swearing "absurd" and "impossible to take seriously" because, when it comes down to it, they start off from concepts that are close to what is commonly accepted as "kid-appropriate" (not even "kid friendly"!), then add elements that are at odds with it... but in such a way that it is clearly "not mature" in itself!
Just because a Sonic character brandishes a realistic gun doesn't mean it suddenly becomes a Call of Duty clone: if the opponents are still purely evil demons and/or faceless mercenaries with little reason behind their existence, the character is still essentially a simple one, the color palette is still colorful, and the effect of the gun is the same as using a spin dash or whatever, you just have given a things that looks mature to a character within a setting that isn't.
If an Asterìx comic directly showed the rape of a woman called Slutrix, by a man called Incelix, and the rest of the comic had Obelix using his superstrenght to track the guy down and then punch him into the sky like the Roman soldiers, all the while Asterìx and Vitastatix comfort Slutrix with shopping, it wouldn't be mature because the rape would not be treated seriously in itself.

If Captain Haddock was presented catching HIV from eating bushmeat, and the comic, while mantaining the canon personalities, talked about it realistically, it would be mature, yes, but it also could be considered "cringe" because it's trying to process a real issue through the lens of fictional characters.

You can have a work that takes a definite partisan stance or expounds an ideological theme (the universal standard theme of good vs evil is partisan, after all), but you should avoid writing these works as explicit 'answers' to concrete, real-world issues. You cheapen the work and cage your writing in what the audience will likely percieve as myopia.
As for whether it 'insults' the audience, I'd argue that anyone who feels slighted by an artist's production, if they were not themselves directly targeted by that artist, is revealing themselves to be ideologically captured and a retard.

I often remind myself that we’re all puppets trapped in a decomposing cage of flesh and bone, with a million desires whirling around us at all times like sirens attempting to lure us to our doom. The world of phenomena is a test, projected by the noumena, and to conquer it you must conquer yourself.

Although I might try to convince myself that life has some external value, after a night drinking with “friends” or a sexual encounter with woman, it quickly becomes apparent that most friends are not worth having, and that woman’s sexual desires are so perverse and banal that their even having desired you bears the weight of a bad conscience. What man does not disgrace himself by submitting to a woman’s desires? He becomes a fool, a brute, a scoundrel, a cuckhold, all at once— and looses himself in the process. What man benefits from society? He devoured his life’s work to the machinations of warfare and industry, he trampled the earth, he becomes bound up in stories told to gullible children, he is sold slavery and like an idiot wears his chains with pride.

Service originates in the Latin word "Servi”, meaning slave. That’s what society, friends, woman the whole world, asks from you, your slavery. In English, the familiar for of “you”, “thou”, has long since died from the language. For those lonely men in Anglo countries seeking company, this should be (with honest reflection) enough proof that you will never find it. We live in a civilizational world-spirit which lacks even the words to express friendship, closeness.

There are two things in life worth their weight in gold: freedom and silence. How many men exchange these treasures for paper? Or for a soft touch of flesh? Or for some false sense of meaning to disguise their emptiness?

In books, there is the peace of forming a genuine connection with another person. If you cannot read, write. If you cannot write, read. If you are still lonely, hire a whore; it is less demeaning and less expensive than going to clubs. Logos is the breaking free of the soul from the flesh, embrace this and turn your eyes from the treachery of desire.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
When, in disgrace with fortune and men’s eyes,
I all alone beweep my outcast state,
And trouble deaf heaven with my bootless cries,
And look upon myself, and curse my fate,
Wishing me like to one more rich in hope,
Featur’d like him, like him with friends possess’d,
Desiring this man’s art and that man’s scope,
With what I most enjoy contented least;
Yet in these thoughts myself almost despising,
Haply I think on thee, and then my state,
Like to the lark at break of day arising
From sullen earth, sings hymns at heaven’s gate;
For thy sweet love remember’d such wealth brings
That then I scorn to change my state with kings.

The description of the beloved is so powerful, but there is no direct compliments. It could basically apply to anyone. I also like the vulnerability shown.

Sonnet 20:
By William Shakespeare

A woman’s face with nature’s own hand painted
Hast thou, the master-mistress of my passion;
A woman’s gentle heart, but not acquainted
With shifting change as is false women’s fashion;
An eye more bright than theirs, less false in rolling,
Gilding the object whereupon it gazeth;
A man in hue, all hues in his controlling,
Which steals men’s eyes and women’s souls amazeth.
And for a woman wert thou first created,
Till nature as she wrought thee fell a-doting,
And by addition me of thee defeated
By adding one thing to my purpose nothing.
But since she pricked thee out for women's pleasure,
Mine be thy love and thy love’s use their treasure.

posts.com:
Remember me when I am gone away,
Gone far away into the silent land;
When you can no more hold me by the hand,
Nor I half turn to go yet turning stay.
Remember me when no more, day by day,
You tell me of our future that you plann'd:
Only remember me; you understand
It will be late to counsel then or pray.
Yet if you should forget me for a while
And afterwards remember, do not grieve:
For if the darkness and corruption leave
A vestige of the thoughts that once I had,
Better by far you should forget and smile
Than that you should remember and be sad.

Sonnet 90 by Petrarch
Upon the breeze she spread her golden hair
that in a thousand gentle knots was turned,
and the sweet light beyond all measure burned
in eyes where now that radiance is rare;

and in her face there seemed to come an air
of pity , true or false, that I discerned:
I had love’s tinder in my breast unburned,
was it a wonder if it kindled there?

She moved not like a mortal , but as though
she bore an angel’s form , her words had then
a sound that simple human voices lack ;

a heavenly spirit , a living sun
was what I saw ; now, if it is not so ,
the wound’s not healed because the bow grows slack.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
On Sitting Down to Read King Lear Once Again

O golden tongued Romance, with serene lute!
Fair plumed Syren, Queen of far-away!
Leave melodizing on this wintry day,
Shut up thine olden pages, and be mute:
Adieu! for once again the fierce dispute
Betwixt damnation and impassion’d clay
Must I burn through; once more humbly assay
The bitter-sweet of this Shakespearian fruit.
Chief Poet! and ye clouds of Albion,
Begetters of our deep eternal theme!
When through the old oak Forest I am gone,
Let me not wander in a barren dream,
But when I am consumed in the fire,
Give me new Phoenix wings to fly at my desire.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Echoes by Roger Waters

Overhead the albatross
Hangs motionless upon the air
And deep beneath the rolling waves
In labyrinths of coral caves
The echo of a distant time
Comes willowing across the sand
And everything is green and submarine
And no one showed us to the land
And no one knows the where's or why's
But something stirs and something tries
And starts to climb toward the light
Strangers passing in the street
By chance, two separate glances meet
And I am you and what I see is me
And do I take you by the hand
And lead you through the land
And help me understand the best I can?
And no one calls us to move on
And no one forces down our eyes
No one speaks and no one tries
No one flies around the sun

> We can make the problem with interactionism clear by superimposing a sketch of the rest of Descartes's theory on his diagram (Figure 2.2).
The conscious perception of the arrow occurs only after the brain has somehow transmitted its message to the mind, and the person's finger can point to the arrow only after the mind commands the body. How, precisely, does the information get transmitted from pineal gland to mind? Since we don't have the faintest idea (yet) what properties mind stuff has, we can't even guess (yet) how it might be affected by physical processes emanating somehow from the brain, so let's ignore those upbound signals for the time being, and concentrate on the return signals,thedirectives from mind to brain. These, ex hypothesi, are not physical; they are not light waves or sound waves or cosmic rays or
streams of subatomic particles. No physical energy or mass is associated with them. How, then, do they get to make a differenceto what happens in the brain cells they must affect, if the mind is to have any influence over the body? A fundamental principle of physics is that any change in the trajectory of any physical entity is an acceleration requiring the expenditure of energy, and where is this energy to come h m ? It is this principle of the conservation of energy that accounts for the physical impossibility of "perpetualbotion machines," and the same principle is apparently violated by dualism. This confrontation between quite standard physics and dualism has been endlessly discussed since Des- cartes's own day, and is widely regarded as the inescapable and fatal flaw of dualism.

Dualists have been silent ever since.

Not him but it's a finish to the paper, like how other parchment papers have a specific finish for their purpose (e.g baking paper is a parchment paper designed to be greaseproof). Parchment itself is the skin of an animal, but parchment paper is a kind of cellulose paper. Generally the ones that have paper stuck on the end are paper, and vellums and other actual parchment won't say paper.
>tl;dr the elephants are vegetables

Instead of lashing out, it may be helpful to try to understand and address the underlying feelings that are driving your behavior. It's important to be understanding and empathetic towards others, even if you don't always agree with their choices or lifestyle. By taking the time to reflect on your own feelings and behavior, you may be able to gain a better understanding of why you are feeling envious and how to move past those negative emotions.

posts.com: LESBIAN SEX WITH JOAN OF ARC

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21383228
One of my favorites. What's impressive about it is that it's Mark Twain's best work (and he also considered it his best), and it's very lovely and reverent towards Joan, despite Twain's life-long atheism. It makes you wonder if he had a Road to Damascus moment near the end of his life, since this was one of the last books he wrote. Most books about Joan of Arc are written from a secular point of view where the author writes her off as mentally-ill, which makes it curious that Mark Twain--a lifelong atheist--treats her visions and revelations as fact.

It's also very accurate, because he spent years in both England and France studying Joan's history, both the English and French side of the Hundred Years' War, and he mastered French to understand the French transcripts of Joan's court trial. The only inaccuracy for the most part is that he refers to Joan as "chief general of France," but no such position actually existed. She might as well have been general, though, because despite the common belief that Joan was merely a figurehead, she actually did have authority and led every charge, despite never personally killing anyone because it was against her beliefs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Nietzsche: "What alone can our teaching be? — That no one gives a human being his qualities: not God, not society, not his parents or ancestors, not he himself... No one is accountable for existing at all, or for being constituted as he is, or for living in the circumstances and surroundings in which he lives. The fatality of his nature cannot be disentangled from the fatality of all that which has been and will be. He is not the result of a special design, a will, a purpose; he is not the subject of an attempt to attain to an 'ideal of man' or an 'ideal of happiness' or an 'ideal of morality' — it is absurd to want to hand over his nature to some purpose or other. We invented the concept 'purpose': in reality purpose is lacking... One is necessary, one is a piece of fate, one belongs to the whole, one is in the whole — there exists nothing which could judge, measure, compare, condemn our being, for that would be to judge, measure, compare, condemn the whole... But nothing exists apart from the whole!— That no one is any longer made accountable, that the kind of being manifested cannot be traced back to a causa prima, that the world is a unity neither as sensorium nor as 'spirit', this alone is the great liberation — thus alone is the innocence of becoming restored... The concept 'God' has hitherto been the greatest objection to existence... We deny God; in denying God, we deny accountability: only by doing that do we redeem the world. — "

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Ecclesiastes

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Alex Kierkegaard: "I need meaning = I want someone to tell me what to do. Same exact business as with 'happiness', etc. When the ultimate goal is an abstract concept like 'meaning' and 'happiness' (or 'good', 'grace', 'redemption' and so on), one can deduce weakness with utter certainty. Strength has concrete, external goals; weakness has abstract internal ones, for the simple reason that we have DEFINED strength and we MEASURE it, in physics as everywhere else, by looking for and comparing EXTERNAL EFFECTS (otherwise the Indian gurus, who routinely defraud their followers with bogus claims of 'inner strength', would rule our societies instead of being laughingstocks of it). No valid argument can be advanced against the above; it simply 'follows from the definition', as mathematicians say. The only question left to ask, then, is if you understand the definition. Do you?"
